text.headline: The History of Music in Chicago
text.text: Many famous artists throughout different genres call Chicago home. Take a look at some of the big names here.

text.headline: Chicago Theatre Opens
text.text: The Chicago theatre opened on Oct. 26, 1921. It was called 'the Wonder Theatre of the World.'

text.headline: Aragon Ballroom Opens
text.text: The Aragon Ballroom has been open on Lawrence Ave. since 1926. According to legend, this bar served as a prohibition-era hangout for Al Capone and friends.

media.caption: A compilation of some of Nat King Cole's best music.

text.headline: Nat King Cole moves to Chicago
text.text: Nat King Cole and his family moved to the Bronzeville neighborhood of Chicago when he was 4-years old. There, he learned how to play the organ, plus he familiarized himself with classical and jazz music.

media.caption: The Staples Singers singing 'Let's Do it Again.'

text.headline: Mavis Staples was born
text.text: Staples was born in Chicago in 1939. She began her singing career with her family group, The Staples, in 1950.

media.caption: Curtis Mayfield and the Impressions singing 'I'm so Proud.'

text.headline: Curtis Mayfield was born
text.text: Mayfield began his singing career in a gospel choir. He met Jerry Butler on the north side of the city and joined his group, The Impressions.

media.caption: Music video for 'Hard to say I'm Sorry,' released in 1982.

text.headline: Chicago forms
text.text: Chicago, the band who describes themselves as rock and roll with horns, was created in 1967. They experienced a lot of success, falling second to the Beach Boys in singles and album charts. They have sold more than 100 million records across the world, and are still touring today.

media.caption: Cheap Trick singing 'I Want you to Want Me' in 1979.

text.headline: Cheap Trick forms
text.text: After growing up in the Chicagoland area, Robin Zander, Rick Nielsen, Tom Petersson and Daxx Nielsen form Cheap Trick. While their three albums did not make it to the top 40 in America, they were very popular in Japan, who called them the American Beatles.

media.caption: One of West's first songs that was never released, titled 'My Way.'

text.headline: Kanye West is born
text.text: Kanye West is one of the most popular rappers to come out of Chicago. After growing up on the south side, he's written many inspirational lyrics about the city. West has experienced a lot of success.

text.headline: Smashing Pumpkins forms
text.text: Billy Corgan, James Iha, D'arcy Wretzky and Jimmy Chamberlain formed the Smashing Pumpkins in 1988. The band gained popularity after producing their second album, The Siamese Dream. They are considered to be one of the most successful bands on the 1990s.

text.headline: Wilco forms
text.text: Still based in Chicago, Wilco formed in 1994. The band has released nine studio albums, a live double album and four collaborations.

text.headline: Fall Out Boy forms
text.text: Patrick Stump, Pete Wentz, Joe Trohman and Andy Hurley grew up in Wilmette, a suburb just north of Chicago. They formed Fall Out Boy in 2001.

media.caption: West's acceptance speech after he wins the Grammy for Best Rap Album.

text.headline: West Wins first Grammy
text.text: 'The College Dropout' won the Grammy for Best Rap Album of the Year. It was also nominated for Album of the Year. This was the first Grammy west won. He has won 21 since.

text.headline: Millenium Park begins Downtown Sound music series
text.text: Also known as free music Mondays, Millenium park hosts weekly free concerts at the Jay Pritzker pavillion. The concert season starts every June and concludes in August.

media.caption: The song that won Staples her first Grammy, 'You are not Alone.'

text.headline: Staples wins her first Grammy
text.text: After being nominated in 2003, Staples won her first Grammy for best Americana Album in 2011 for 'You Are Not Alone.'
